newsitem.title: INDIA: Delhi shares end a shade lower on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Delhi shares end a shade lower on profit-taking.

text.p: A slow down in buying by financial institutions coupled with profit-taking by speculators drove share prices to a marginally lower close on the Delhi Stock Exchange on Tuesday, brokers said.
The bourse's benchmark index closed 1.38 points lower at 717.18.
Traders said speculative selling in the absence of strong buying continued to underpin the prices.
"Selling by financial institutions was mainly responsible for the decline in share prices," said Suresh Aggarwal of brokers Jaimata Securities.
Brokers said the fall could have been much sharper.
"Some short covering by bear operators managed to arrest the declining pace to some extent," said Harjit Wadhwa of brokers Wadhwa and Associates.
Reliance Industries, after fluctuating wildly in volatile trade, closed one rupee higher at 238 rupees, brokers said.
TISCO dropped 1.35 rupees to 187.65 on institutional selling, they said.
